wikipedia_page.main: Allen Algernon Bathurst, Lord Apsley, DSO, MC, TD, DL (3 August 1895 – 17 December 1942) was a British Army officer and Conservative Party politician.

response: *1895 – Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley, English politician (d. 1942)
*1942 – Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley, English lieutenant and politician (b. 1895)

link_mentions.page: List of political families in the United Kingdom

response: On his death the titles passed to his eldest son, the seventh Earl. He was for some years the owner of the Morning Post. Lord Bathurst's eldest son and heir apparent Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley, was Member of Parliament for Southampton and Bristol Central. In 1942 he was killed in the Second World War, predeceasing his father by one year. His wife Viola Bathurst, Lady Apsley, succeeded him as Member of Parliament for Bristol Central. Lord Bathurst was succeeded by his grandson, the eighth Earl, who held political office under Harold Macmillan as a Lord-in-waiting (government whip in the House of Lords) from 1957 to 1961 and as Joint Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department from 1961 to 1962.  the titles are held by his son, the ninth Earl, who succeeded in 2011.
*Lt-Col Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley (3 August 1895 – killed on active service 17 December 1942)
The eldest son of Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley, and his wife Violet (née Meeking), he was educated at Eton College, Ridley College, St. Catharines, Ontario, Canada, and Christ Church, Oxford.
*Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley; MP for Southampton (1922–1929) and Bristol Central (1931–1942)
*Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley (1895–1942), British Member of Parliament for Southampton and Bristol Central
In 1933, he flew with Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley from England to Australia.
* Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley (1895–1942), British Army officer

response: After circulation had fallen dramatically, in December 1922 she decided to sell the paper, assigning her son Allen Bathurst, Lord Apsley, to handle the negotiations. Negotiations with Rupert E. Beckett of The Yorkshire Post began in 1923, but were unsuccessful. On 7 April 1924 the paper was sold to Alan Percy, 8th Duke of Northumberland, and a consortium of prominent Conservatives for £500,000 (£ in ).
